summary: This is an email chain from February 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing the technical process of uploading and reviewing data from devices seized in the Epstein investigation. The emails focus on managing large volumes of data in a document review platform (Relativity), segregating privileged material, and coordinating with the FBI's Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART).

persons.name: Korologos
persons.context: Email participant from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, providing updates on data loading and segregation for privilege review.

events.title: Receipt of FBI CART Hard Drive
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office receives a hard drive from the FBI's Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) containing processed data from devices seized in the Epstein case.

events.title: Release of NP Folder
events.description: An 'NP folder' (likely meaning non-privileged) is released within the document review system.

events.title: Data Management Discussion
events.description: Email discussion about locating and reorganizing a large set of data (37 subfolders) related to subpoena returns within the document review platform.

keyFacts: The FBI's Computer Analysis and Response Team (CART) processed data from devices seized in the Epstein investigation and provided it to prosecutors on a hard drive.
The U.S. Attorney's Office was managing a 'voluminous' amount of seized data, requiring technical coordination for upload and privilege review in the Relativity platform.
The process involved segregating data into categories like 'Search Warrant Returns', 'Subpoena Returns', and separating privileged (PP) from non-privileged (NP) material.
The correspondence shows ongoing evidence management and review efforts in early 2020, after Epstein's death in August 2019.
